Rationale for classification: Since there is description that "irritation or caustics" is shown as the effect of chromate to the skin (IRIS (1998), DHP (13th, 2002)), and the dichromic acid potassium of the similar compound was classified into category 1(ID 262, Chemical Abstracts Service:7778-50-9), it was set as category 1A-1C. In addition, further categorizing from this data is difficult.

Name: O,O-Diethyl O-2-quinoxalinyl phosphorothioate; Quinalphos
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1983)): "Slight erythematous responses were noted at 24 hours. By 72 hours, the reactions cleared up" (though the Draize score is not presented).

Name: disul
Rationale for classification: Although there is a report that 5% or more of aqueous solutions caused the necrosis on the skin of the rabbit(ACGIH (2001)), irritation is taken in the ICSC card and the EU risk phrase. It is thought that the solution with 5% or less concentration and solid powder causes only irritation on skin contacts. It was classified as Category 2.

Name: Methyl 2-(4,6-dimethoxy-2-pyrimidinyloxy)-6-[1-(methoxyimino)ethyl]benzoate
Rationale for classification: Based on test data from rabbit skin irritation studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)): "Caused mild irritation which persisted for up to 72 hours."

Name: Decabromo-1,1'-biphenyl
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (PATTY (4th, 2000)): "Mild rash and edematous response occurred at the abraded and intact skin sites in four of six treated animals" and the substance is "classified as an only mild skin irritant."

Name: potassium dicyanocuprate
Rationale for classification: There is no data of this product. But there is description that cyanide has weak skin irritations (CICAD(J)61(2004)), and it was set to Category 3.

Name: mecrilate
Rationale for classification: The severe irritation is reported for Draize test on rabbits (RTECS, 2004). Moreover, skin irritations with repeated exposure on human is reported (CICAD, 2001; ACGIH, 2001). Therefore, it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Thiram
Rationale for classification: From the description that the skin of the rabbit is stimulated very slightly (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Zinc bis(N,N'-dimethyldithiocarbamate)
Rationale for classification: Based on test data from rat skin irritation studies (exposure duration unknown) (IUCLID (2000)): "Mild irritation."

Name: butyl lactate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the moderate irritation was acknowledged by application on the skin of the rabbit (RTECS (2005)).

Name: enflurane
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statement that the skin may be stimulated and redness and dryness may be caused (ICSC (J) (2002)) .

Name: nitrilotriacetic acid
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions that it irritates human skin (HSFS (2001), SITTIG (2002)), and "As this article is a strong acids, it is supposed to have irritation. There is no laboratory reports." (CERI Hazard Data (2002)), So it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Subtilisins, as crystalline active enzyme
Rationale for classification: Irritation on human skin is reported. But there is no information on the extent (ACGIH, 2001). Therefore, it was classified as Category 2-3.

Name: Benxyl acetate
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 because of the statement of moderate on rabbits (RTECS (2005)).

Name: Ethyl acrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the results of rabbit temporary skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 59 (2004)): The substance, when applied for 4 hours, causes the formation of crusts, necrotic mass and severe erythema/edema associated with cicatrices; it is considered "corrosive."

Name: Butyl acrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on statement that moderate to severe erythema and dropsy are observed on rabbits (SIDS (2002)), that there is skin irritation on humans and that the skin disease of papular erythematous was observed (SIDS (2002), DFGOT vol.5 (1993)), and the fact that it is classified into Xi; R36/37/38 in EU (EU-Annex I (2005)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: 2-Aminoethanol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on animal skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-41 (2002), ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "Corrosive" and "irritating, necrosis," the substance is thus considered "corrosive."

Name: 3-Penten-2-one, 4-methyl-   (Mesityl oxide)
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions that rabbits had mild or marked skin irritation (PATTY(5th, 2001) vol.6) and that redness, pains and dermatitis on humans are observed (ICSC (J) (1998), HSDB (2005)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: anilinium chloride
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from the description that there is irritation to humans (Moderate, RTECS (2004)), and the result that  Standard Draize Test to rabbit (ICSC (J), (2001), HSFS (2003)).

Name: piperazine dihydrochloride
Rationale for classification: From description that mild to moderate skin burn was acknowledged in the human acute evidence of exposure (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was judged as skin irritation and set as Category 2.

Name: Heptane
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that irritant was acknowledged by the cutaneous contact as effect of the humans (DFGOT (vol.11, 1998) and Occupational Health Recommendation of Occupational Exposure Limits(1988)).

Name: triammonium trioxalatoferrate
Rationale for classification: By the skin standard Draize's dexamination (HSDB, 2005;RTECS, 1997) of a rabbit, since the reaction of the skin was Moderate (score 3.06), it was set as Category 2.

Name: disodium tri(cyano-C)cuprate(2-)
Rationale for classification: There is no data of this product. But there is description that cyanide has weak skin irritations (CICAD(J)61(2004)), and it was set to Category 3.

Name: Sodium cyanide
Rationale for classification:
Based on the following description found in CICAD (2004): "Cyanide is slightly irritating to the skin and eye", although no data is available for sodium cyanide.

Although the present substance is a salt of a weak acid and a strong base and the pH of its aqueous solution is expected to exceed 11.5, no description specifying the pH could be found, so classification by pH was not conducted.

Name: fluoroacetic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
It was set as Category 1A-1C from description that there was caustic to humans (ICSC (J), (1995), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when subdivision needs to be performed.

Name: N-methyldithiocarbamic acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of destruction of skin tissues observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (24 hour application) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

Name: Oxalic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 1 based on the statements that burn was produced on a local skin regions with airborne dust on humans (ACGIH (2001)) that corrosivity is indicated to the skin (ICSC (J), (1996)).

Name: ferbam
Rationale for classification: From description that dermatitis is caused to part humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.18, 2002)), it was judged that there was skin irritation and, it was set as Category 2.

Name: endothal
Rationale for classification: Since severe irritation was indicated to skin of rabbits as a result of the skin irritation study using a rabbit (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1994)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Tributyltin chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rat skin irritation tests (EHC 116 (1990)): "The substance induced widespread epidermal necrosis within 12-24 hours. Regeneration of the epidermal layer was observed at 18-24 hours. No inflammatory infiltration was found in the dermis. At 5 hours, erythema reached a maximum and remained through 48 hours. By 72 hours, erythema reactions had resolved." The substance is thus considered to cause strong irritation with reversible effects, and classified into Category 2.

Name: m-Phenylene-bis(methylamine)
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: From description that caustic is in the skin of the guinea pig by apply of a stock solutions (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and description that internal bleedings were acknowledged in 3 minutes, the necrosis was acknowledged 5 minutes afterward, and the erythema of the skin, dropsy, bleeding, and a necrosis were acknowledged in the all examples of six animals 60 minutes afterward by apply on the rat skin (SIDS (2001)), and bleeding and a necrosis were acknowledged within 60 minutes by skin apply to a mouse, it was judged that there was caustic, and it was set as Category 1B.

Name: dinitolmide
Rationale for classification: Since contact eczema was acknowledged in human occupation evidence of exposure, and from description that it was a skin test positivity (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was judged that it was skin irritation and it was set as Category 2.

Name: ethoxydimethylsilane
Rationale for classification: It showed slight to moderate stimulativeness in the skin irritation test on rabbits (ACGIH 7th, 2001).Therefore, it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Hexanoic acid, 2-ethyl-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions, "Although undeluted liquid caused slight edema, erythema and necrosis, deluted liquid by 20% caused no or very slight edema and slight to moderate reddening" (Patty (5th, 2001)) in the study of 24 hour dermal administration to guinea pig and "slight necrosis in 5 animals and subsequent formation of slight to moderate crusts ," also in the 4 hour administration of undeluted liquid to 6 rabbits. Furthermore, there are descriptions "corrosive" in 3 cases of the 24 hour dermal stimulation study of rabbits, one of which is the result of the rabbits study in 1986 mentioned above. Although there is a description, on the other hand, "not irritating" in the dermal stimulation study (OECD TG 404, GLP) using rabbits in IUCLID (2000), delution conditions are unknown, because the primary document is a company report. Since there was a dose-dependent datum on guinea pig in the year 1955 and the existence of 3 cases in IUCLID (2000) where data were evaluated as "corrosive" without any description about recoverability could not be neglected, it was classified in Category 1.

Name: Phenol, 4-methoxy-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from descriptions that the skin of the guinea pigs was stimulated to mild or moderate (PATTY (4th, 1994)), and that it was the skin irritation without concrete case report (HSDB (2005), HSFS (2000), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Sodium dodecan-1-yl sulfate
Rationale for classification: It was classified into Category 2 with no description of recovery properties despite the description of "highly irritating" from PII: 6.0 and 6.78 (ECETOC TR66 (1995), IUCLID (2000)) in the skin irritation and corrosion test with rabbits (OECD TG 404, GLP).

Name: Potassium cyanide
Rationale for classification:
Based on the following description found in CICAD (2004): "Cyanide is slightly irritating to the skin and eye", although no data is available for potassium cyanide.
Although the present substance is a salt of a weak acid and a strong base and the pH of its aqueous solution is expected to exceed 11.5, no description specifying the pH could be found, so classification by pH was not conducted.

Name: Aziridine
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It is known that this product produces a burn on human skin. Since the case where it caused refractory dermatitis has been reported (CERI Hazard Data, 2002), it was classified as Category 1. But detailed classifications cannot be performed because of insufficient data.

Name: cartap hydrochloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: All of the result of the examination (an original object and five examinations by a tablet) of the rabbit of Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1994) were corresponsive to the outside of category. But technical products of this product is valued pH2 or less, and it was set to category 1A-1C. In addition, further categorizing is difficult.

Name: p-Phenetidine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (24 hour application) (CERI Hazard Data 2000-25 (2001) and SIDS (1995)): "slightly irritating."

Name: trans-1,2-Dichloroethylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "moderate skin irritation" from the rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2000-46 (2001)), though the results are not those of 4-hour application.

Name: Cyanamide, calcium salt (1:1)
Rationale for classification: Based on the diffuse nature expansive redness and itchiness on human skin and formation of induration, ulcer, and crust on rabbit skin since (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2000)), and it was classified as R38 in EU-Annex, it was classified as Category 2.

Name: alpha,alpha,alpha-trifluoro-2,6-dinitro-N,N-dipropyl-p-toluidine
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation, which were fully reversed within 14 days, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1989)).

Name: ''mercurous oxide''
Rationale for classification: From the description with the possibility which indicates skin irritation in humans (DFGOT, vol.15, 2001 [as inorganic mercury compounds]; HSFS, 2001[irritate and burn]), it was thought that there was irritation and it was set as Category 2.

Name: 2-chloro-2',6'-diethyl-N-(methoxymethyl)acetanilide
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation with a Draize score of 2.0, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2000)).

Name: Mercury diacetate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): The substance causes "skin burn and pain; Corrosive to the eye/skin/respiratory tract; Oral ingestion produces corrosive effects." The substance is thus considered corrosive to the skin and classified into Category 1A-1C. However, it should be placed in Category 1, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: 2-Norbornene, 5-ethylidene-
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions that it has skin irritativeness and caused redness on humans (PATTY (5th, 2001)), and the result of the rabbit skin irritation study with four hour application was "slight" to "mild" (SIDS (2004)). Therefore, it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Methyl t-butyl ether
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that moderate to serious dropsy and moderate erythema were acknowledged in the study applied to the skin of the rabbit for 4 hours (EU-RAR (2002)).

Name: N,N-Dimethyldodecylamine N-oxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-26 (2002)): "24-hour application induced severe irritation of the skin."

Name: Sodium sulfide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Described only irritating as a result of a rabbit examination (IUCLID (2000)). But there is  description with corrosive irritant to skin as human impact (HSDB (Access on Jun 2005)). And also there is description that it was corrosive chemical (HSFS (1999)), it was set as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Dipotassium hexafluorosilicate
Rationale for classification: Since there was description (ICSC, 1994) that a stimulus of the human skin, reddening, and a pain, it thought that there was mild irritation and it was set as category 3.

Name: Borate(1-), tetrafluoro-, hydrogen
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
It was set as category 1A-1C since there is the description that there is caustic to human skin and severe burns is caused (HSDB, 2003;  ICSC (J), 1995; SITTIG, 4th, 2002; HSFS, 1999), and it was set as "C;R34" by EU-Annex I (Access on Jul.2005).
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when further categorizing needs to be performed.

Name: Silicate(2-), hexafluoro-, disodium
Rationale for classification: From the description of redness and the pain which stimulate the human skin (ICSC, 1994;SITTIG, 2002) and the description of a mild degree stimulus and weak congestion in the rabbit skin (RTECS, 2003;IUCLID, 2000), it thought that there was mild irritation and it was set as category 3.

Name: tetrachloroauric acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
This product data was not found. But the this product was classified into the caustic substances according to UNRTDG, it was taken as Category 1A-1C.
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when further categorizing needs to be performed.

Name: ammonium hexafluorosilicate
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 2 from the description (HSDB, 2003; SITTIG, 2002; HSFS, 2000) that stimulates the human skin strongly and possibility of ulcers.

Name: Hexafluorosilicic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
Since there was description of "corroding the skin" to humans (ICSC (2004), SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and was also classified into "C;R34 (Causes burns)" of European risk phrases, it was set as category 1A-1C.
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when further categorizing needs to be performed.

Name: dipotassium peroxide
Rationale for classification: "If touched to solid, a burned will be caused on the skin."(HSDB (2005)) From this statement, it judged that there was skin irritation and was set as Category 2.

Name: monensin
Rationale for classification: From the description that it stimulates human and rabbit skin at mild (Mild) degree (HSDB, 2002; RTECS, 2005), it was set as category 3.

Name: O-Ethyl S,S-diphenyl phosphorodithioate; Edifenphos; EDDP
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (HSDB (2006)): "Slightly irritating."

Name: Barium hydroxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "severe irritation" from skin irritation tests in rats and rabbits (exposure duration unknown). Also based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (CERI Hazard Data 2001-56 (2002)): "soluble barium compounds cause irritation of the eye, skin, nose, throat and bronchi. In particular, aqueous solutions of barium hydroxide are strongly alkaline and severely irritate the eye and skin." Also based on the description in CICAD (2001) (exposure duration unknown): "Barium hydroxide is strongly alkaline and therefore corrosive."

Name: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo[b,e][1,4]dioxin
Rationale for classification: From description that hyperkeratosis and epidermal hyperplasia were accepted in the acute dermatitis exposure tests using the mouse (ATSDR (1998)), and description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J) (2003)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: N-[2-[1-(4-Chlorophenyl)-1H-pyrazole-3-yloxymethyl]phenyl]-N-methoxycarbamic acid methyl ester
Rationale for classification: It was set to category 3 according to the technological direction based on the statement that the average value of the marks of erythema was 1.8 and the average value of edema were 0.4 as a result of the skin stimulus examination using rabbits (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: decaborane(14)
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 from description that the human skin was stimulated (ICSC, 1997; HSDB, 2005; SITTG, 4th, 2002).

Name: Benomyl
Rationale for classification: Since mild irritation was observed in the test on rats (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: O,O-Diethyl O-5-phenyl-3-isoxazolyl phosphorothioate; Isoxathion
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1985)): "The substance is slightly irritating with effects resolving after 3 days" (though the Draize score is not presented).

Name: 1,1-Dimethyl-4,4-bipyridinium dichloride
Rationale for classification: In Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1991), several reports describe that the moderate stimulativeness was seen in 20% paraquat solution (several additive agents other than water are included) on rabbits skin irritation study, and redness and sloughing were seen in the pesticide formulations acute dermal toxicity tests on rats, etc. Therefore, it was thought to have relatively strong skin stimulativeness and classified as Category 2.

Name: 2-Pyridinecarboxylic acid, 4-amino-3,5,6-trichloro-
Rationale for classification: Since there were descriptions of mild irritant on human skin (ICSC (J) (1995), HSDB (2005), HSFS (2001), SITTIG (4th, 2002)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: diborane(6)
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions that it has skin stimulativeness on humans (HSDB (2006)) and skin corrosiveness especially (ICSC (1990)), it was classified as Category 1A-1C. Moreover, there is also a description of critical frostbite (ICSC (1990)).

Name: 2-Chloro-6-(trichloromethyl)pyridine
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on the statement that it has a possibility of causing irritation and disorder to the skin on contact (SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: pentaborane(9)
Rationale for classification: There was no animal examination data. But it was set as Category 2 from the description "strong stimulativeness and a burn may be caused by skin contacts" (HSFS (2000)).

Name: N'-(4-chloro-o-tolyl)-N,N-dimethylformamidine monohydrochloride
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 from description that the rabbit skin is stimulated slightly (EHC199 (1998)).

Name: Stannane, tributylfluoro-
Rationale for classification: From the statement that the this product indicates skin irritation which is mild (minimal) (ATSDR, 2005) and the knowledge that the tributyl tin compound or the organotin compound indicates skin irritation (DFGOT 1, 1991-atty 5th, 2001;ATSDR, 2005), it was set to category 3

Name: o-chlorostyrene
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions regarding rabbit test of "irritant" (HSDB (2002)) and that "the substance is irritating to the eyes and the skin" (ICSC (2002)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: paraquat-dimethylsulfate
Rationale for classification: Since there was information that it stimulated human skin (ACGIH (2001)) and animal skin (EHC 39 (1984)), it was classified as "Category 2." In repeated exposure, skin necrosis is also seen on rats and mice. (EHC 39(1984))

Name: Blasticidin S
Rationale for classification: Since there is the description that rash on the human skin is caused, that a toxic effects is acknowledged to be to the skin, and that pathologic changes is seen on membrane as well as on the skin (HSDB, 2004), it was judged that it had slight skin stimulativeness leastways, and was set to category 3.

Name: osmium tetraoxide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the information that it has corrosive effects and caused serious dermatitis and blister on human cases(ACGIH (2001)) and (PATTY (5th, 2001)).

Name: aluminium phosphide
Rationale for classification: There is description which indicates skin irritation on human (SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (1998), ICSC (J) (1997)). But the test data used as the determined indicators of Category 2 or 3 was not found, it was set as Category 2 from a viewpoint of safety.

Name: O-Ethyl O-4-nitrophenyl phenylphosphonothioate; EPN
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1988)): "The substance caused slight skin irritation which resolved within 72 hours."

Name: caesium hydroxide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: There are Mild reports when it attaches to the skin of a rabbit in the state of the dry crystal (RTECS (2004)). But it indicates significant corrosive (ACGIH (2001)) when it is absorbed moisture, or in aqueous solutions. So it was set as Category 1. The warnings and the cautions about corrosion behavior for humans are also indicated by individual references (ACGIH (2001), HSFS (1998), Sitting (47th, 2002)). It is referred to as class 8PG II in the U.N. transportation advice. GHS Category for the purpose of transportation is set as 1B.

Name: 2-[(Thiocyanatomethyl)sulfanyl]-1,3-benzothiazole
Rationale for classification: There is a description, "strong skin irritation" (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (2008)) in the dermal stimulation study with rabbits. Furthermore, when a cited literature, U.S. EPA 73-R-05-003 (2006) was checked, there was a description, "The score 72 hours later was 7.42 and severe erythema and edema were observed." Since there is no descriptipn of irreversibility, it was classified in Category 2. Incidentally, EU division is Xi; R36/38 EU-Annex I)

Name: 2-(4-chloro-6-ethylamino-1,3,5-triazin-2-yl)amino-2-methylpropiononitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (24 hours, occluded) (PATTY (4th, 1999)): "Mildly irritating."

Name: Mercury monoxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): "reddening, irritation of the eye/skin/respiratory tract." The substance is thus considered to possess a skin irritation potential of unknown degree and could be placed in Category 2 or 3. It is classified as Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 2,3-epoxypropyl o-tolyl ether
Rationale for classification: It was classified in Category 2 based on the description, "being stimulative" (ICSC (2005)). EU-Annex I shows Xi; R38, which corresponds to the GHS Category 2. There is, however, a description, "slight irritation" (IUCLID (2000)), in the study using rabbits based on the OECD Gideline 404 and comforming to GLP. The data corresponding to this substance among the information of CAS No. 26447-14-3 were used for the data of IUCLID (2000).

Name: S-Ethyl hexahydro-1H-azepine-1-carbothioate; Molinate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation with a Draize score of 1.83 at 24 hours, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1985)).

Name: Fenamiphos
Rationale for classification: From evaluation results of several rabbit skin irritation tests that "not a primary irritant" (JMPR 929 (1997)), "minimal irritation" (JMPR 929 (1997)) or "only slightly irritant" (PATTY (5th, 2001)), it was judged to have mild irritativeness and was classified as Category 3.

Name: octachloronaphthalene
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statement that it may stimulate human skin and cause skin rash (HSFS (2000)).

Name: 2,2'-[oxybis(methylene)]bisoxirane
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from descriptions that severe irritation which produced erythema, edema and eschar was acknowledged in the test using the rabbit (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and that severe irritation and chemical burn were acknowledged when single time application was done in the rabbit skin (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: arsenic pentachloride
Rationale for classification: There was no data of this product. But it was set as category 2 based on that arsenic chloride (ID 1091, Chemical Abstracts Service 7784-34-1) is classified into category 2 since it stimulates the human skin (seriously).

Name: O,O-Diethyl S-(6-chloro-2,3-dihydro-2-oxobenzoxazolinyl)methyl phosphorodithioate; Phosalone
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the human health effects (HSDB (2003)): "moderately irritating."

Name: 2-(4-tert-butylphenoxy)cyclohexyl 2-propynyl sulfite
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests performed according to EPA Guideline 81-4 (IUCLID (2000)): "Moderately irritating."

Name: Oxirane, (butoxymethyl)-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated as effect of the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.4, 1992), PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: 2-(Dimethylamino)ethyl acrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of skin corrosivity from the rabbit primary skin irritation tests (three reports in SIDS (2003)) and lack of data for subclassification, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Triglycidyl isocyanurate
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions that  TGIC operating workers show human skin irritation (NICNAS (1994)), and that mild moderate skin irritation on rabbits (CERI Hazard Data (2002), CICADS 8 (1998), ACGIH (7th, 2001), and NICNAS (1994)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Styrene, methyl-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin of the humans was stimulated (NTP TR 375 (1990)), and from description that irritation was admitted by the test applied to the skin of the rabbit (IUCLID (2000), RTECS (2005)).

Name: Polymer of 4,4'-isopropylidenediphenol and 1-chloro-2,3-epoxypropane (liquid); Bisphenol A type epoxy resin (liquid)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit primary skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-36 (2002), DFGOT vol.19 (2003)): The substance does not cause or causes moderate irritation to the skin, though the results of 4-hour application are not available. The substance is considered "irritating."

Name: Nonylphenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.1 (2004)): "Prolonged exposure to nonylphenol produces corrosive effects on the skin." Also based on the description in EU-RAR No.10 (2002): "Based on the results obtained in two studies, it is reasonable to consider nonylphenol to be corrosive on contact with skin." Although classified into Category 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Benzene, dinitro-
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 from the statements of slight irritation in rabbit test (IUCLID (2000)) and skin irritation on humans (HSDB (2005)).

Name: Tris(dimethylphenyl) phosphate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.24 (2005)): "Slight erythematous responses persisted by 72 hours."

Name: Sodium dodecylbenzenesulphonate (C12)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (24 hour application) (RTECS (2006)): "Causes moderate irritation." Also based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests performed in accordance with OECD TG 404 (IUCLID (2000)): "Irritating to the skin." Although the results are not those of 4 hour application, the substance is considered to be a moderate irritant and classified into Category 2.

Name: chlorophenol
Classification: Skin corrosion / irritation - o-:Category 1A-1C, m-:Category 2, p-:Category 1A-1C
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
o-body: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the statements that serious stimulativeness and corrosion were observed on rabbits (ATSDR (1999)) and that there were redness and pain on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)).
m-body: It was classified as Category 2 based on the statement that there are redness and pain on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)).
p-body: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the statements that there were serious stimulativeness and corrosiveness for animals (ATSDR (1999), RTECS (2004), and IUCLID (2000)) and that there are redness and pain on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)). In addition, monochlorophenol is reported to have corrosivity on animals (ATSDR (1999)).

Name: O-Ethyl O-2-(isopropoxycarbonyl)phenyl N-isopropylphosphoramidothioate; Isofenphos
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hour application) (IUCLID (2000)): "Slightly irritating."

Name: (N-(1,1,2,2-Tetrachloroethylthio)-1,2,3,6-tetrahydrophthalimide); Captafol
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 by description that there was moderate irritation to the skin of the rabbit (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and by description that many stimulative and allergic examples of contact dermatitis development of symptoms were reported in the agriculture and forestry pursuers of handling KYAPUTAFORU in Kumamoto, other domestic areas, and New Zealand (PIM 097 (1990), ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

Name: Tridecylbenzenesulphonic acid (C13)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on tridecylbenzenesulphonic acid per se).

Name: Benzene, trimethyl-
Rationale for classification: Since it had descriptions that there were primary skin irritation (animal species were unknown) (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), moderate irritation to a rabbit (RTECS (2005)). And also skin irritation as human impact without the concrete case report were shown ( HSDB (2005), HSFS (2003), and SITTIG (4th 2002)). So it was set as Category 2.

Name: methylcyclohexanol
Rationale for classification: It was seto as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated in the humans (ICSC (J) (2001), HSDB (Access on Jume 2005), SITTIG (4th, 2002)), description that there was possibility of skin irritation (HSFS (2000)), and description that transient erythema was seen by repeated dermal exposure to the rabbit (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: 5-ethoxy-3-trichloromethyl-1,2,4-thiadiazole
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of irritation reactions (Draize score of 1.7), with some improvement occurring during 72 hours of observation, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

Name: Terphenyl
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the rabbit skin was stimulated to moderate (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

Name: Sodium tridecylbenzenesulphonate (C13)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on sodium tridecylbenzenesulphonate per se).

Name: 2-[(Tolyloxy)methyl]oxirane
Rationale for classification: Based on the description, "Draize score 5.2/8, moderate skin irritaqtion,"(Patty (5th, 2001)) in the study with rabbits it was classified in Category 2. Incidentally, EU division is Xi; R38 (EU-Annex I).

Name: Methyl-1,3-phenylene diisocyanate; m-Tolylene diisocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the following descriptions in DFGOT Vol. 20 (2005) suggesting its irreversible effects, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety: "on the surface of the skin as well as necrosis and the formation of granulomas (rabbit 24-hour skin irritation tests)" and "undiluted TDI 80/20 was evaluated as caustic. The skin was visibly healing, but the changes were not completely reversible within the follow-up period of 8 and 28days (1- or 4-hour skin irritation tests)".

Name: Sodium azide  (Na(N3))
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It judged to be "Category 1C" from corrosivity in animal test result and 4 hour contact (DFGOT vol.20 (2003)).

Name: [(2-chlorophenyl)methylene]malononitrile
Rationale for classification: Since there was a result of Mild in skin application test on rodent (RTECS (2004)), it was classified as "Category 3."

Name: sulphuryl difluoride
Rationale for classification: There is no data about skin corrosivity/stimulativeness. It was set as category 2 in order to call attention, since chilblain may be started by touching the liquid when the this product is in state of a compressed liquefied gas (ICSC (J), (2001), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: tricalcium diarsenite
Rationale for classification: From description that irritation is indicated as an inorganic arsenic compound (PIM 042, 1996;DFGOT vol.21, 2005), it was judged that it had slight irritation and it was set as Category 3.

Name: Dodecylbenzenesulphonic acid (C12)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (2002) of the human health effects: "redness, pains, skin burn and bullae." The substance is classified into Category 2 because the severity of the effects is unknown.

Name: Sodium undecylbenzenesulfonate (C11)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on sodium undecylbenzenesulfonate per se).

Name: Tetrabromo(tetrabromophenyl)benzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on dermal studies in rabbits (EHC 152 (1994)): The technical mixtures tested "induced moderate erythematous and slight edematous response."

Name: dinoseb acetate
Rationale for classification: Since there was description that the skin is stimulated to "Mild (slight)" as a result of Standard Draize Test (Adoption 24 hours) to a rabbit (RTECS (1997)), it was set as Category 3.

Name: Antimonate(2-), bis[mu-[2,3-di(hydroxy-kappaO)butanedioato(4-)-kappaO1:kappaO4]]di-, dipotassium, trihydrate, stereoisomer
Rationale for classification: Since it is supposed that there is skin irritation (HSFS (2004) and SITTIG (4th, 2002)) and there also the statement that the this product in ointments indicates mild irritation in early stages of use (a rash is produced in long-term uses) (HSDB (2005)), it was set as category 3.

Name: Sodium tetradecylbenzenesulphonate (C14)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on sodium tetradecylbenzenesulphonate per se).

Name: 2-(Dimethylamino)ethyl methacrylate
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It is classified as "Category 1A-1C"in the three-ministry GHS division. Since UN GHS Document 3.2.2.4.2 says, "For those authorities wanting more than one designation for corrosion, up to three sub-categories are provided within the corrosive category." subdividing is not essential. It is therefore preferable to modify "Category 1A-1C" to "Category 1" from the view point of text representation as well.

Name: Cyclopentane
Rationale for classification: Since there is a description that contact with this product may stimulate human skin (SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (2001), ICSC (J) (1994)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Chlorpyrifos
Classification: Skin corrosion / irritation - Not classified (applicable to 72% Water dispersible granule)
Rationale for classification: Since irritation was not observed in the skin irritation test of 72% granules hidrated agent on rabbits (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: clopidol
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions that the skin may be stimulated (SITTIG (47th, 2002), HSFS (2000)), it was thought that it had mild irritation and was classified as Category 3.

Name: Parathion, methyl-
Rationale for classification: In rabbit skin application test, descriptions "although very slight to moderate erythema was observed, all recovered within 48 hours" and "mild irritation" are found. Therefore it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Ronnel
Rationale for classification: Based on the description as which hyperemia of the only slight skin was regarded by the examination of the rabbit (ACGIH (2001)), and the description of having felt the irritation for the skin of the human face (HSDB (2005)), it was set as Category 3.

Name: 4-tert-butyl-2-chlorophenyl methyl methylphosphoramidate
Rationale for classification: From description that slight erythema was admitted in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit (the exposure time was unknown) (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was judged that there was mild irritation, and it was set to Category 3.

Name: naled
Rationale for classification: Since ACGIH (2002) describes that severe skin irritations was observed on rabbits and that dermatitis was observed in human exposure case, it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Lead diacetate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2002) of the acute effects on humans: "reddening and pain" in the affected skin (the severity of which is unknown).

Name: Hydrazine
Rationale for classification: Due to lack of data for subclassification, though the results of rabbit skin irritation tests suggest irritating reaction, with fatal cases reported in some subjects, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Ethanamine, 2,2'-oxybis[N,N-dimethyl-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: From description that necrosis was accepted by the test applied to the rabbit skin (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was judged that there was caustic, and it was set as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Paraformaldehyde
Rationale for classification: It was seto as Category 2 from description that severe irritation was admitted by the test using the rabbit (RTECS (2005)),  and description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J) (1996), HSDB (2005), HSFS (2000), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: 4-methyloxetan-2-one; (+/-)-4-methyloxetan-2-one
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the moderate irritation was acknowledged by application on the skin of the rabbit (RTECS (2005)).

Name: Tetradecylbenzenesulphonic acid (C14)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on tetradecylbenzenesulphonic acid per se).

Name: aldrin
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 from description that very slight erythema was observed with skin contacts on humans (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: Decylbenzenesulfonic acid (C10)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on decylbenzene sulfonic acid per se).

Name: o-Chlorinated diphenyl oxide
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on descriptions that severe skin irritations was seen on rabbits (HSFS (2000)) and that rash and warmth was caused within a short time after exposure on humans (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: bromacil
Rationale for classification: In the skin irritation test using a guinea pigs, it was the effects of exposure, mild irritation was seen for 24 hours (Agricultural -Chemicals abstracts). So it was set as Category 3.

Name: N,N-Dimethyl-1,2,3-trithian-5-amine
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on the statement (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) that mild skin irritations was seen in the rabbit.

Name: 1,2-Dichloro-3-nitrobenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (HSDB (2005)): "The substance induced slight delipidation of the skin surface, with sloughing in days 7-10. At 24 hours, severe erythema and edema were evident. These irritant reactions gradually subsided and there was no injury in depth. The substance is thus considered to possess a severe skin irritation potential" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application).

Name: 3-(Methylsulfanyl)propanal
Rationale for classification: A result of "slight irritation" and that of "necrosis" are described in SIDS (2003) for the 4-hour skin irritation test using rabbits. Since SIDS (2003) has drawn a conclusion, "There is skin irritation," based on many experimental results including these, it was classified in Category 2.

Name: Diuron
Rationale for classification: Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1996) Since slight erythema was seen on the healthy skin of three among ten in the primary skin irritation test on guinea pigs, it was classified as Category 3. ACGIH (7th, 2001) and ACGIH-TLV (2005) report that there are skin irritations.

Name: Decanoic acid
Rationale for classification: Since there is a description, "moderately to severely irritating" (IUCLID (2000)) in the 24-hour administration study with rabbits, it was classified in Category 2.

Name: diazomethane
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 as it was reported that there is stimulativeness and denudation on human skin (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: temephos
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on the statement that mild irritation was seen in the animal (PATTY (5th, 2001), RTECS (2004)), and the statement that there was irritant by contact in humans (HSFS (2000)).

Name: 3,5,5-Trimethyl-1-hexanol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4-hour application) (SIDS (2003)): "Draize scores for 24, 48, and 72 hours: Erythema = 1.83, Edema = 0.22 and PII = 2.08" and "moderate irritation."

Name: carbonyl difluoride
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J)(2003), HSDB (2005), HSFS (1999), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: 4-methyloxetan-2-one; (+/-)-4-methyloxetan-2-one
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the moderate irritation was acknowledged by application on the skin of the rabbit (RTECS (2005)).

Name: sulfotep
Rationale for classification: There are results that skin irritation was not observed on rabbit (ACGIH and (2005), DFGOT vol.13 (1999), and PATTY (5th, 2001)), however, there are many descriptions on humans that it stimulates skin and causes disorder (ACGIH (2005), ICSC (J), (1999), HSDB (2005), HSFS (2000), SITTIG (2002)). Since there was no statement about the disorder and concrete description or a grade of the stimulativeness on humans, taking the larger side with danger, it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Potassium chlorate
Rationale for classification: There was no result of laboratory animals. But it was thought that there was mild irritation from the description of "skin redness and the skin are stimulated" (HSDB, 2002;SITTIG, 4th, 2002;ICSC, 1998;HSFS, 2004), and it was set to category 3.

Name: dinocap
Rationale for classification: Since there is the description that human skin is stimulated (ICSC (J), (1997), HSDB (2003)), it was set as category 2.

Name: 2,3-epoxypropyl isopropyl ether
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on the report that moderate skin irritation was observed on rabbits (PATTY (5th, 2001)).

Name: Cyclohexane, 5-isocyanato-1-(isocyanatomethyl)-1,3,3-trimethyl-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since there are statements about severe irritation on humans (HSDB (2003)) and corrosivityity and severe necrosis and edematous on rabbits (IUCLID (2000), CERI Hazard Data (2000)); it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: O-4-bromo-2-chlorophenyl O-ethyl S-propyl phosphorothioate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1984)).

Name: 2-Butenal
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was taken as Category 1 from the descriptions that it had skin irritation as an impact to human (IARC 63 (1995)) and that it could be classified as corrosive with serious erythema, dropsy, and nonreversible chemical burn with average PII of 8.0/8.0 in the 4-hour skin irritation tests in rabbits (HSDB (2005)). European Union classification: Xi; 38 (EU-Annex I) is equivalent to the GHS Category 2.

Name: Cyanamide
Classification: Skin corrosion / irritation - Not classified(about 10% liquid product)
Rationale for classification: Based on the test result of rabbit examination (solution with 13.33% purity), irritation was not observed(Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts (2002)), and it was classified as out of Category.

Name: Ketene
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on the statement that redness arises with severe irritation on humans (ICSC (J) (1997), HSDB (2005)).

Name: 1,1'-Dimethyl-4,4'-bipyridinium salts (except paraquat dichloride)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rat skin irritation tests (EHC 39 (1984)): "The substance induced dermatitis associated with erythema, edema, desquamation and necrosis." The substance is classified into Category 1A-1C given the absence of data on severity of corrosion, but should be placed in 1A, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: N-methyl-N,2,4,6-tetranitroaniline
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that there was skin irritation as effect of the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994), DFGOT (vol.1, 1998)).

Name: Formaldehyde
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rabbit skin irritation tests (EHC 89 (1989)): "mild to moderate" and data on human health effects (EHC 89 (1989)).

Name: D.D.T.
Rationale for classification: There is description that irritation was not admitted by a human dermal exposure tests (EHC 9 (1979)). But from description that the slight or moderate skin irritation was suggested in the test using the rabbit (PATTY (4th, 1994)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Benzo[a]pyrene
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the irritation accompanied by erythema and burning sensations was in the skin in the humans (HSDB (2005), HSFS (1998), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Aspirin
Rationale for classification: There are findings in animal studies that irritation is mild (IUCLID (20000)), ut that there is irritation on humans (ACGIH (2001), ICSC (J) (1998)).

Name: 2-Pyridinamine
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions "The skin is stimulated" as effect of short-term exposure (ICSC (2004)) and "because of strong alkalis, mild to moderate skin irritation is expected"(PATTY (5th, 2001)). Based on these description, this product was judged to have mild irritation and it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Ethane, 1,1'-thiobis[2-chloro-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that edema of the skin and blister formation are seen by humans evidence of exposure (DFGOT (4 vol. 1992), ATSDR (2003)).

Name: Silver cyanide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin primary irritation tests (RTECS (2005)): "Mild," though the results are not those of 4-hour application. The substance is thus considered a "mild irritant."

Name: cyanogen chloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Irritation on the human skin is observed in the state of steam, and when being a liquid (13degC or less), it becomes stronger and is described that it "will burn skin" (HSDB (2003)). Moreover, it is described as "when touching liquid: frostbite" (ICSC (1999)). Based on above, it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Undecylbenzenesulfonic acid (C11)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on undecylbenzenesulfonic acid per se).

Name: 2,4-Dinitrophenol
Rationale for classification: The substance is classified into Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety, based on the description in the report on guinea pig skin irritation tests (ATSDR (1995)): "moderately irritating," though the results of rabbit skin irritation tests suggest the substance is "mildly irritating" (CERI Hazard Data 99-9 (2000)).

Name: Chlorobenzilate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (RTECS (2006)): "Mildly irritating to the skin."

Name: 2-chloro-2',6'-diethyl-N-(2-propoxyethyl)acetanilide
Rationale for classification: Based on test data from rabbit skin irritation studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1983)): "Moderately irritating."

Name: Methylenebis(4,1-cyclohexylene) diisocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "The substance produced severe skin irritation." Also based on the description in the report on guinea pig skin irritation tests: "severe erythema and edema were observed." Although the substance, as a severe skin irritant, is classified into Category 1-2 in the absence of data on reversibility, it should be placed in Category 1 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 1,2-Dinitrobenzene
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 from the statement that it might stimulate human skin (HSDB (2005)).

Name: 2-chloroacetophenone
Rationale for classification: The chemical burns was seen on humans (IRIS (1981)), and erythema, edema and exfoliation was reported for animals (ACGIH (2001)), therefore, it was classified as Category 2 .

Name: Carbonic acid, sodium salt (2:3)
Rationale for classification: There was a stimulative (irritating) statement to the skin of humans (HSDB (2003), ICSC (2004)), and the complaint of the skin condition based on a stimulation was reported by the mining workers who received occupational exposure (HSDB (2003)). So it was set as Category 2.

Name: 4,6-Dinitro-o-cresol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (DFGOT vol.19 (2003)): "The substance causes moderate irritation."

Name: 1,2-Dichloroethylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from the rabbit skin irritation test using trans-1,2-dichloroethylene (CERI Hazard Data 2000-46, 2001), although no data were available for 1,2-dichloroethylene (mixture).

Name: bis(acetato-O)dioxouranium
Rationale for classification: Since there was description that human skin is stimulated (HSDB (2002), HSFS (2000)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: 5-methylheptan-3-one
Rationale for classification: Based on the result of rabbit Draize test of "mild" (RTECS (2004)) , it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Propene, 1,3-dichloro-
Rationale for classification: Since slight erythema and dropsy was observed in rabbit skin irritation study and also seen 14 days afterward, as well as exfoliation on 4 out of 6 rabbits (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1997), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Trichloroacetonitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (24 hour application) (RTECS (2003)): "Severe irritation was observed."

Name: hydroxylammonium chloride
Rationale for classification: Since there is the description which indicates skin stimulation (redness, pain) in Priority 2 (ICSC (1997)) and R36/38 is indicated of European risk phrases, it was set as category 2.

Name: 1,2,4-Bbenzenetricarboxylic 1,2-anhydride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hours): "mild irritation was observed" (SIDS (2003)), and "mild irritation" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-33 (2002)).

Name: (3,5,6-trichloro-2-pyridyl)oxyacetic acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1996)).

Name: trisodium trioxalatoferrate
Rationale for classification: There is no this product data.But soluble iron salt is supposed to indicate the skin irritation (ACGIH-TLV (2006)). It was set as category 3.

Name: O-6-Chloro-3-phenyl-4-pyridazinyl S-n-octyl thiocarbonate; Pyridate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (IUCLD (2000)): "Irritating" (though the severity of the effects is unknown).

Name: 2,3-epoxypropan-1-ol
Rationale for classification: Since there are discriptions of moderate irritation on rabbits (ACGIH (2001), PATTY (5th, 2001)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Methyl isothiocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions in the reports on rabbit skin irritation tests: "Moderate" (though the results are those of 24 (not 4) hour application) (RTECS (2006)) and "strongly irritating" (exposure duration unknown) (HSDB (2006)). The substance is thus considered a moderate skin irritant.

Name: Magnesium stearate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on what the possibility of skin irritations for humans was indicated (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Zinc stearate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on what the possibility of the skin stimulus for humans is indicated (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: carbon tetrabromide
Rationale for classification: Since it was indicated that the effect which suggested the stimulativeness of degrees from very mild to moderate was admitted as a result of the skin irritation study in a rabbit on PATTY (4th, 1994), it was judged with Category 2.

Name: Tetrachloromethane
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" in rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 67, 2005).

Name: Distannoxane, hexabutyl-
Rationale for classification: Since severe irritation was indicated in the Draize's examination using human and rabbit skin (RTECS, 2004) and it was considered as the powerful skin stimulativeness substance (CICAD 14, 1999), it was set as Category 2.

Name: tributyltin acetate
Rationale for classification: From the knowledge that the skin is stimulated and a burn injury is caused (HSFS, 1999), and that tributyltin compounds or organic tin compounds indicate skin irritation (DFGOT 1, 1991-atty 5th, 2001; ATSDR, 2005), it was judged that it had slight skin irritation leastways, and was set as category 3.

Name: Parathion
Rationale for classification: It is based on the test result on rabbits (a mild irritant) (JMPR (1995)).

Name: barium tetracyanoplatinate
Rationale for classification: There is no data of this product. But the water-soluble barium compounds are supposed to indicate skin irritation (ACGIH-TLV (2006)). Since there is description that each of barium (107 EHC (J), 1990) and cyanide (61 CICAD (J), 2004) indicate mild skin irritations, it  was set to Category 3.

Name: 3-Chloro-2-methylprop-1-ene
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of corrosion (PII=7.25) (DFGOT vol.4 (1994), IUCLID82000)) in the skin irritation/corrosion test with rabbits (OECD TG 404), it was classified into Category 1. Incidentally, EU division is R34 (EU-Annex I), corresponding to Category 1.

Name: 2-Butanone, 3-methyl-
Rationale for classification: There was no animal test data in application of less than 4 hours. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the moderate irritation was admitted in the test applied to the skin of rabbit and guinea pig for 24 hours (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: Hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on mouse skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.206 (2005)): 0.5, 1 and 2 hour application "caused moderate irritation of the skin."

Name: propiolactone
Rationale for classification: From description that skin burns (blistering of the skin, hair loss, and scarring) was seen in humans evidence of exposure (HSDB (Access on May 2005)), and description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J), (1997), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and irritation (erythema-scarring) was accepted with mouse (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: chlordane , pur
Rationale for classification: It is reported that when human skin was irritated by exposed  (HSDB (2005), HSFS (2005)), a feeling of warmth, itching, and rash often appear (ATSDR (1994), HSFS (2005)). Animal data which follows standard skin irritation test is not found. But in single or repeated exposure tests, description that "a severe irritation is caused" is seen about skin symptoms (EHC 34 (1984)). Based on what mentioned above, this product is thought to have irritativeness and it was classified as Category 2.

Name: 2,6-Xylenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit and guinea pig skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)): "erythema and ulceration were observed." Also based on the description of human effects: "the substance causes chemical burn and corrosion of the skin and mucosal membranes at the site of contact" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)). Although classified as Category 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 4-(2,4-dichlorobenzoyl)-1,3-dimethyl-5-pyrazolyl 4-toluenesulfonate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild reversible irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1978)).

Name: Butyric acid, 2-hydroxy-4-(methylthio)-
Rationale for classification: It was set to category 2 from the description that mild irritation (slight;4 hr) is indicated in the rabbit skin or a middle degree stimulus (Moderate; 24 hr) is indicated in vitro test (IUCLID, 2000).

Name: 4-Methyl-1,3-phenylene diisocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of "severe" found in the RTECS report (2005) on rabbit skin irritation tests, suggesting that the substance induces at least mild skin irritation, although it is unclear whether the tests were 4-hour tests, and based on the fact that the substance is classified as "Xi (irritant)"by EU Risk Phrase.

Name: m-Aminophenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (RTECS (2004)): "Mild."

Name: calcium cyanide
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statement that redness and stimulation on human skin were observed (ICSC (J), (1998)).

Name: mercury dicyanide
Rationale for classification: There is description that the skin is stimulated (HSDB (2005), HSFS (1993), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and it was set as Category 3.

Name: mercury dithiocyanate
Rationale for classification: From description with the possibility which indicates skin irritation in humans (DFGOT, vol.15, 2001[as inorganic mercury compounds]; STTIG, 4th, 2002;HSFS, 1993), mild irritation was considered to be a certain thing, and it was set to Category 3.

Name: Methanesulfenyl chloride, trichloro-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that skin of guinea pig and rabbit were stimulated seriously (PATTY (4th, 1994)) .

Name: 1,1-dichloro-1-nitroethane
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 as it showed irritation in rabbit skin test (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Zinc acetate, dihydrate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in EHC 221 (2001): Twenty-percent solution of zinc acetate causes mid skin irritation (slightly less irritant) ((though the results are not those of 4-hour application). The substance is considered "mildly irritating" to the skin.

Name: bromoacetone
Rationale for classification: It was set to category 2 from the description that stimulus on the human skin at serious degree (Severe), redness, and hurts  were seen (ICSC(J)2005; HSDB, 2003; HSFS, 2002).

Name: Propionic acid, 2-chloro-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions that it is corrosive with rabbits and guinea pigs (ACGIH and (2001), IUCLID (2000)) and that a severe burn occurs on humans(HSDB (2005)), and the fact that it is classified as C:R35 in EU (EU-Annex I (2005)), it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: 4-dimethylaminoazobenzene
Rationale for classification: It classified into Category 2 according to description which stimulated person's skin and caused dermatitis (IARC Vol.8 (1975), HSDB (Access on May 2005), HSFS (2003), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Ethane, 1,1'-oxybis
Rationale for classification: There is a result of having no skin stimulativeness in rabbit test (DFGOT vol.13 (1999)). However, on the other hand, there is also a description of mild irritativeness in a rabbit test (RTECS (2005)). Although severe irritation is reported for guinea pig test (RTECS (2005)), it was 24 hour exposuretest, and it was regarded as a reference. Based on two examinations on rabbits and EU R phrase: Xn; R66, it was classified as Category 3.

Name: methylhydrazine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that erythema and edema were observed in dog skin application test, though the exposure time was unknown (ACGIH (7th, 2004) and PATTY (4th, 1994)) and that there is possibility of severe damage on human skin (PATTY (4th, 1994)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: acetamide
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions "it has comparatively no irritativeness to the skin or mucous membrane (HSDB (2003))" and "the skin and eye are stimulated as effect of short-term exposure (ICSC (1997))", it was judged to have slight irritativeness and classified as Category 3.

Name: 1-chloro-1-nitropropane
Rationale for classification: Based on the report that slight erythema is observed on rabbits (DFGOT vol.1 (1991)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Amitrol
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions "although slight erythema was observed only with higher doses, recovered in 48 hours" and "a very slight stimulativeness was found" as results of two skin irritation study on rabbits (EHC 158 (1994), ACGIH (2001)). Moreover, as for humans, mild irritations in occupational exposure and slight dermatitis on three persons among six in 24-hour apply patch tests are reported (EHC 158 (1994)). Since very slight stimulativeness was reported both on humans and animals as mentioned above, it was classified as out of Category 3.

Name: 4-methoxy-m-phenylenediamine
Rationale for classification: It was classified as "Category 3" because there was a result of Mild in examination on rabbits (DFGOT vol.6 (1994)).

Name: ethyl methylnitrosocarbamate
Rationale for classification: There is no concrete case report. But from description that a blister is made by contact (PATTY (4th, 1994)), it was judged that there was skin irritation, and it was set as Category 2.

Name: Uranyl acetate dihydrate
Rationale for classification: Since there was description that human skin is stimulated (HSDB (2002)), it was set as 2.

Name: Chlordimeform
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 from description that skin of rabbits is stimulated slightly (EHC199 (1998)).

Name: Hydrogenated terphenyl
Rationale for classification: Although there are descriptions, "moderately irritating, PII value=3.01" and "not irritating, PII value = 0.04" (IUCLID (2000)) in the information source of List 2 in the 24 hour Draize test using 2 rabbits, irritation caused with this substance cannot be denied, because there is a description, "There is a moderate irritation in the rabbits' skin" in the information source of List 1. Therefore, it was classified in Category 2.

Name: Ammonium undecylbenzenesulfonate (C11)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on ammonium undecylbenzenesulfonate per se).

Name: Phenylmercury acetate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "reddening, pain, blurred vision and severe deep burn" (ICSC (J) (2005)).

Name: ethyl methanesulphonate
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the skin might be stimulated by contact (HSFS (2000)), and description that the skin was stimulated (SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Aniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit skin irritation test (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.63 (2004) and EU-RAR No.50 (2004)): "moderate irritant".

Name: Dimethyl 2,2-dichlorovinyl phosphate; Dichlorvos
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2003)): The substance produced mild reversible irritation of the skin.

Name: dimethylnitrosoamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the report of irritativity on human skin (ICSC(2001); Patty, 5th (2001)) and the statement of "not significantly irritating to the skin" (Patty, 5th (2001)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Methane, isocyanato-
Rationale for classification: It was estimated as Moderate as a result of Draize test on rabbits, and it was reported that it also cause irritations or damages on humans (RTECS (2004)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Dimethyl disulfide
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on the description that moderate to severe erythema and edema were observed on rabbits (ECETOC TR66 (1995), PATTY(5th, 2001) vol.7).

Name: Pentyl acetate
Rationale for classification: The isomer mixture was classified as Category 3 based on the observation of two rabbit skin irritation tests (the isomer mixture used as the test substance): "slight stimulativeness" and "moderate erythema, slight dropsy, and slight scaling seven days after application" (DFGOTvol.11 (1996)). In addition, there is discription that "disappearance by volatilization of the remarkable rate of a study substance could be considered at the time of application" for the examination where repetitive application of the isomer mixture on human skin. And 197 subjects did not observe irritation at all (DFGOTvol.11 (1996)).

Name: Carbaryl
Rationale for classification: Transient erythema was observed in the test on rabbits (EHC 153 (1994)) and mild irritation and warmth appeared in the skin in exposure test to humans, they recovered in several hours (PIM 147 (1997), ACGIH (2001)). Threfore it was classified as Category 3.

Name: dimercury di(acetate)
Rationale for classification: From the description with the possibility which indicates skin irritation in humans (DFGOT, vol.15, 2001 [as inorganic mercury compounds]), it was thought that there was mild irritation and it was set as Category 3.

Name: Propane, 2-ethoxy-2-methyl-
Rationale for classification: Based on the Draize score of P.I.I.3.03 (Moderate Irritant) in test on rabbits (ACGIH (2002)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: phenylphosphine
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (2001), HSDB (2005), and HSFS (2001)).

Name: triphenyltin chloride
Rationale for classification: Since the burn injury was seen in the human skin (HSDB, 2003) and the strong reaction was seen in the skin of rats (RTECS, 2004;HSDB, 2003), it was set as category 2.

Name: Formic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It has corrosive damage on human skin(PATTY and (5th, 2001), NTP TR19 (1992), ICSC (J) (1997)), and severe irritation and corrosivity are also observed for animals (DFGOT vol.19 (2003), PATTY (5th, 2001), IUCLID (2000)). These statements and C:R35 of the EU classification were judged collectively, and it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Acetic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Skin necrosis and burn (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and corrosion (IUCLID (2004))were observed with application of acetic acid at 50% or more of concentration in animal experiments. Also based on EU-Annex 1:C;R35, etc. it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Diethyl sulfate
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: From description that the necrosis arose by application on the skin of the rabbit (CERI Hazard Data (1996) and DFGOT (vol.20, 2003)), it was judged that there was caustic and it was set as Category 1A-1C.

Name: S-2-(Ethylthio)ethyl O,O-dimethyl phosphorodithioate; Thiometon
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (RTECS (2006)): "Mild."

Name: 1,3-Dioxolane
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 from the statement of "mild" of the rabbit examination (RTECS (2004)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), straight-run middle
Rationale for classification: It was highly irritating in rabbit skin irritation tests. But it was classified as Category 2 because description of irreversible lesions is not observed (IUCLID (2000), EHC (1006)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on several reports which observed mild irritation in rabbit tests (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on several reports which observed mild irritation in rabbit tests (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Ammonium nitrate
Rationale for classification: There is description that skin irritation was not admitted by the test using the rabbit (IUCLID (2000)), it was set to category 2 since ICSC (J) (2001), HSDB (2005), HSFS (1998), and SITTIG (4th, 2002) had no report of specific cases but there is description that the skin of what is indicated and is not may be stimulated.

Name: nicotine sulphate
Rationale for classification: In Priority 2, since there was description which indicates irritation to human skin (ICSC (J), (1997), SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (2002)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: cicloheximide
Rationale for classification: Since there is a stimulate of "Moderate (moderately)" in Standard Draize Test in a rabbit (RTECS (2004)), and there was description that the human skin is stimulated (ICSC (J), (1997), HSDB (2002), SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (1999)), it was set as category 2.

Name: Esfenvalerate
Rationale for classification: Since there is description that human skin is stimulated slightly (ICSC (J), (2004)), and irritation was slightly indicated in the test using a rabbit (JMPR (2002)), it was set as Category 3. In addition, also refer to a fenvalerate (ID 269, Chemical Abstracts Service:51630-58-1).

Name: alpha-cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl 2,2-dimethyl-3-(1,2,2,2-tetrabromoethyl)cyclopropanecarboxylate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based the publication (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) of the skin irritation test using a rabbit, in which slight erythema of 5/6 animal were seen after 24 hours after, very slight erythema of 3/6 animal were seen after 72 hours, and all of them were disappeared six days after.

Name: Chloroform
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "slight congestion in the skin, moderate skin necrosis and incrustation" (EHC 163, 1994) from the rabbit skin irritation test, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Ethane, hexachloro-
Rationale for classification: There is description that irritation was not acknowledged in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit (PATTY (4th, 1994), NTP TR361 (1989), and ATSDR (1997)). But it was set as Category 3 from description that slight skin irritation was acknowledged in the example of repetitive exposure of the humans (IARC 73 (1999), ATSDR (1997)).

Name: (S)-alpha-Cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl 3-(2,2-dichlorovinyl)-2,2-dimethyl-cis-cyclopropanecarboxylate; alpha-Cypermethrin
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (EHC 142 (1992)): "Mildly irritating."

Name: 4-Methylideneoxetan-2-one
Rationale for classification: Since there is a description, "4.9 Draize units" (IUCLID (2000)) and the study of a cited literature (Ind. Hyg. Found. Am. Chem. Toxicol. Ser. Bull. 6 (1967)) showed the rsult corresponding to "moderate irritation", it was classified in Category 2. In addition, there are descriptions, "moderate"RTECS (2006) in the 24 hour Draize test with rabbits and "mild" in the study with rabbits. Moreover, there is a description, "corrosive, severe heat-burns in the eyes and skin" (HSDB (2003)).

Name: methylphosphonic dichloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
